query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
1 «Vexilla regis prodeunt inferni 2 verso di noi; però dinanzi mira», 3 disse ’l maestro mio, «se tu ’l discerni».
query.result:
**English:**
1 The banners of the king of hell advance 2 towards us; therefore look ahead,” 3 said my master, “if you can make them out.”
**Old English:**
1 Þæs hellewæringes cyninges tacen 2 usweard cumað; forðy sceawa nu,” 3 cwæð min lareow, “gif ðu hit geseon miht.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
4 Come quando una grossa nebbia spira, 5 o quando l’emisperio nostro annotta, 6 par di lungi un molin che ’l vento gira,
7 veder mi parve un tal dificio allotta; 8 poi per lo vento mi ristrinsi retro 9 al duca mio, ché non lì era altra grotta.
query.result:
**English:**
4 As when a thick fog breathes, 5 or when our hemisphere darkens at night, 6 a mill from afar seems to be turning in the wind,
7 I seemed to see such a structure then; 8 then because of the wind I drew back behind 9 my guide, for there was no other shelter there.
**Old English:**
4 Swa ðonne þicce mist byð, 5 oððe wonn niht ofer wera bearnum, 6 þonne bið lyftdræg lyt, swylce hweowol bered,
7 þuhte me ðæt ic gesawe swylce; 8 þa ic ðurh ðone wind wæs wædum bewunden, 9 æfter þam lareowe, forðam ðær nan weg næs.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
10 Già era, e con paura il metto in metro, 11 là dove l’ombre tutte eran coperte, 12 e trasparien come festuca in vetro.
query.result:
**English:**
10 It was already, and with fear I put it into verse, 11 there where all the shadows were covered, 12 and they shone through like a straw in glass.
**Old English:**
10 Hit wæs ða, and ic mid ege ðæt mæne, 11 ðær ða sceаdu ealle wæron oferðeаhte, 12 and ðurhscinen swilce festuc in glæsе.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
13 Altre sono a giacere; altre stanno erte, 14 quella col capo e quella con le piante; 15 altra, com’ arco, il volto a’ piè rinverte.

Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
16 Quando noi fummo fatti tanto avante, 17 ch’al mio maestro piacque di mostrarmi 18 la creatura ch’ebbe il bel sembiante,
19 d’innanzi mi si tolse e fé restarmi, 20 «Ecco Dite», dicendo, «ed ecco il loco 21 ove convien che di fortezza t’armi».
query.result:
**English:**
16 When we had come so far forward, 17 that it pleased my master to show me 18 the creature that had the beautiful form,
19 he removed himself from before me and made me stop, 20 saying, "Behold Dis, and behold the place 21 where it is necessary for you to arm yourself with strength."
**Old English:**
16 Þa we wæron swa feor gegangene, 17 ðæt ðam lareowe licode ðæt he wolde me æteowian 18 ða gesceaft ðe hæfde ðone fægeran hiw,
19 he aforðode hine fram me and dyde ðæt ic ðær gestod, 20 and cwæð, "Efne Dis," and cwæð, "and efne ðeos stow 21 ðær ðe gedafenað ðæt ðu ðe mid strengðe geweorðige."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
22 Com’ io divenni allor gelato e fioco, 23 nol dimandar, lettor, ch’i’ non lo scrivo, 24 però ch’ogne parlar sarebbe poco.
query.result:
**English:**
22 How I became frozen and faint then, 23 do not ask me, reader, for I do not write it, 24 because all speech would be feeble.
**Old English:**
22 Hu ic ða wearð aforht and forðyrst, 23 ne asca ðu me, lareow, forðæm ic hit ne write, 24 forðæm ðe eall spræc bið to lyt.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
25 Io non mori’ e non rimasi vivo; 26 pensa oggimai per te, s’hai fior d’ingegno, 27 qual io divenni, d’uno e d’altro privo.
query.result:
**English:**
25 I did not die, and I did not remain alive; 26 now think for yourself, if you have a spark of intelligence, 27 what I became, deprived of both life and death.
**Old English:**
25 Ic ne swealt ne ic ne lyfde; 26 ðence nu ðu ðe selfum, gif ðu hæfst ænigne ingeþonc, 27 hwæt ic wearð, begengra læs.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
28 Lo ’mperador del doloroso regno 29 da mezzo ’l petto uscia fuor de la ghiaccia; 30 e più con un gigante io mi convegno,
31 che i giganti non fan con le sue braccia: 32 vedi oggimai quant’ esser dee quel tutto 33 ch’a così fatta parte si confaccia.
query.result:
**English:**
28 The emperor of the realm of pain 29 emerged from the ice up to the middle of his chest; 30 and I felt more kinship with a giant,
31 than the giants do with his arms: 32 now you can see how huge that whole body must be 33 that is proportionate to such a part.
**Old English:**
28 Se casere ðæs wælhreowan rīces 29 of middes ðæs breostes út ða ūt gewāt; 30 and mā mid anum giganta ic me gecīgde,
31 ðonne ðā gigantas ne dōð mid heora earmum: 32 geseoh nu ðonne hū micel sēo eall sēo wæs 33 ðe swylcum dæle swā gemet wæs.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
34 S’el fu sì bel com’ elli è ora brutto, 35 e contra ’l suo fattore alzò le ciglia, 36 ben dee da lui procedere ogne lutto.
query.result:
**English:**
34 If he was as beautiful as he is now ugly, 35 and raised his eyebrows against his maker, 36 then every sorrow must proceed from him.
**Old English:**
34 Gif he wæs swa fæger swa he nu is atol, 35 and ongean his Scyppend his neb awende, 36 ðonne mot of him yfel cuman.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
37 Oh quanto parve a me gran maraviglia 38 quand’ io vidi tre facce a la sua testa! 39 L’una dinanzi, e quella era vermiglia;
40 l’altr’ eran due, che s’aggiugnieno a questa 41 sovresso ’l mezzo di ciascuna spalla, 42 e sé giugnieno al loco de la cresta:
43 e la destra parea tra bianca e gialla; 44 la sinistra a vedere era tal, quali 45 vegnon di là onde ’l Nilo s’avvalla.
query.result:
**English:**
37 Oh, how great a marvel it seemed to me 38 when I saw three faces on his head! 39 The one in front, and that was vermilion;
40 the other two, which joined this one 41 above the middle of each shoulder, 42 and met at the place of the crest:
43 and the right one seemed between white and yellow; 44 the left one, to look at, was such 45 as those who come from where the Nile descends.
**Old English:**
37 Eala, hu micel wundor ðuhte me, 38 ða ic ðreo ansyna on his heafde geseah! 39 Þæt an wæs beforan, and ðæt wæs read;
40 ða oðre wæron tu, ða wæron fæste 41 ofer ðæs mûðes ðæs midlestan, 42 and ða ða ðridde fæste ofer ða:
43 and ðæt ðæs swiðran ansyn wæs hwit and geolu; 44 ðæs wynstran ansyn wæs swilce ða, 45 ða ðe cumað of ðam lande ðær Nilus offealled.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
46 Sotto ciascuna uscivan due grand’ ali, 47 quanto si convenia a tanto uccello: 48 vele di mar non vid’ io mai cotali.
query.result:
**English:**
46 Beneath each one emerged two mighty wings, 47 as befitting such a bird: 48 I never saw such sails on the sea.
**Old English:**
46 Underneðan him ðær wæron twægen micle wengan, 47 swilce ðam fugle gebyrede, 48 næfre ic on sæge seolh swilce geseah.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
49 Non avean penne, ma di vispistrello 50 era lor modo; e quelle svolazzava, 51 sì che tre venti si movean da ello:
52 quindi Cocito tutto s’aggelava.
query.result:
**English:**
49 They had no wings, but of a bat 50 was their fashion; and they fluttered them, 51 so that three winds were stirred up by them:
52 Cocytus was frozen entirely by this.
**Old English:**
49 Ne nawæron him ða wæteras feðre, 50 ac wæron ðæs fleogeandes hrycg, 51 swa ðæt ða ðreo windas ðær of comon:
52 ðanon Cocytus eal geguren wæs.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
53 Con sei occhi piangëa, e per tre menti 54 gocciava ’l pianto e sanguinosa bava.
55 Da ogne bocca dirompea co’ denti 56 un peccatore, a guisa di maciulla, 57 sì che tre ne facea così dolenti.
query.result:
**English:**
53 With six eyes he wept, and down three chins 54 the tears and bloody foam ran mingled; 55 at every mouth he crushed a sinner 56 with his teeth, like a brake, so that he made 57 three of them suffer thus.
**Old English:**
53 Mid sixe eagum he weop, and þurh þreo muðas 54 rann ðæt tear and ðæt blodige slabb. 55 Of ælcre muðe he mid his toðum 56 bræc anne synfullne, swylce mæssepreost, 57 swa ðæt he þreo mid ðan dolge dyde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
58 A quel dinanzi il mordere era nulla 59 verso ’l graffiar, che talvolta la schiena 60 rimanea de la pelle tutta brulla.
query.result:
**English:**
58 Compared to the biting, the scratching was nothing 59 to that in front, which sometimes left 60 the back completely stripped of skin.
**Old English:**
58 Wið ðone ðe ðær beforan wæs ðæt bitan 59 næs naðing to ðam clammum, ðe ðær hwílum 60 ðone hrycg wyrston ealne of ðære hide.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
61 «Quell’ anima là sù c’ha maggior pena», 62 disse ’l maestro, «è Giuda Scarïotto, 63 che ’l capo ha dentro e fuor le gambe mena.
query.result:
**English:**
61 "That soul up there who suffers the greatest pain," 62 said the master, "is Judas Iscariot, 63 whose head is inside and whose legs stick out."
**Old English:**
61 "Se sawl ðær uppe ðe ða mæstan sar hafað," 62 cwæð se lareow, "is Iudas Scarioð, 63 ðe ðæt heafod hafað innan and ða legas wrixleð."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
68 Ma la notte risurge, e oramai 69 è da partir, ché tutto avem veduto».
70 Com’ a lui piacque, il collo li avvinghiai; 71 ed el prese di tempo e loco poste, 72 e quando l’ali fuoro aperte assai,
73 appigliò sé a le vellute coste; 74 di vello in vello giù discese poscia 75 tra ’l folto pelo e le gelate croste.
query.result:
**English:**
68 But night is rising, and now 69 it is time to depart, for we have seen everything.
70 As it pleased him, I clasped my arms around his neck; 71 and he took his time and chose his place, 72 and when his wings were spread wide,
73 he clung to his hairy sides; 74 then he descended from hair to hair 75 between the thick fur and the icy crusts.
**Old English:**
68 Ac niht astyreð, and nu ða gen 69 is to farenne, forðæm ðe we habbað eall gesewen.
70 Swa ðam leofan men leofre wæs, ic his hals umbefeng; 71 and he ða genam ða tid and ða stowe, 72 and ða ða ða wæron ða wengan fulle atogene,
73 ða afæstnode he hine sylfne ðam ruwan sidan; 74 of hare ða to hare he nyðer astah 75 betwux ðam þyccan hare and ðam cealdan is.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
76 Quando noi fummo là dove la coscia 77 si volge, a punto in sul grosso de l’anche, 78 lo duca, con fatica e con angoscia,
79 volse la testa ov’ elli avea le zanche, 80 e aggrappossi al pel com’ om che sale, 81 sì che ’n inferno i’ credea tornar anche.
query.result:
**English:**
76 When we were there where the thigh 77 turns, right at the point of the haunch’s bulk, 78 the leader, with effort and with anguish,
79 turned his head where he had his legs, 80 and clutched the hair like a man climbing, 81 so that I thought I was returning to hell again.
**Old English:**
76 Þa we wæron þær ðær ðeo ðeoh 77 gewent, æt ðæs miclan sceonces ende, 78 se heretoga, mid geswince and mid angan,
79 gewende his heafod þær he hæfde ða scencan, 80 and feng to ðam fexe swa man deð ðe stigeð, 81 swa ðæt ic wende eft to helle faran.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
82 «Attienti ben, ché per cotali scale», 83 disse ’l maestro, ansando com’ uom lasso, 84 «conviensi dipartir da tanto male».
query.result:
**English:**
82 “Pay close attention, for by such stairs,” 83 said the master, panting like a weary man, 84 “one must depart from so much evil.”
**Old English:**
82 “Gehyrst ðu wel hwæt ðurh ðas stige,” 83 cwæð se lareow, “ðe ðus gewæht hafast, 84 man sceal ðurh ðas yfel gewendan.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
85 Poi uscì fuor per lo fóro d’un sasso 86 e puose me in su l’orlo a sedere; 87 appresso porse a me l’accorto passo.

Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
94 «Lèvati sù», disse ’l maestro, «in piede: 95 la via è lunga e ’l cammino è malvagio, 96 e già il sole a mezza terza riede».
query.result:
**English:**
94 "Arise," said the master, "on your feet: 95 the way is long and the journey is evil, 96 and already the sun returns to mid-third."
**Old English:**
94 "Aris," cwæð se mæster, "on fotum: 95 lang is ðeos weg and se wæstm is yfel, 96 and nu ða sunne to midde þære tierce cyrreð."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
97 Non era camminata di palagio 98 là ’v’ eravam, ma natural burella 99 ch’avea mal suolo e di lume disagio.
query.result:
**English:**
97 It was not a path for a palace, 98 the place where we were, but a rough and narrow path, 99 which had a bad surface and was difficult to see.
**Old English:**
97 Nis ðis weges gemet to healle, 98 ðær we wæron, ac steap upflora, 99 se ðe hæfde grundlease and lytle leoht.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
100 «Prima ch’io de l’abisso mi divella, 101 maestro mio», diss’ io quando fui dritto, 102 «a trarmi d’erro un poco mi favella:
103 ov’ è la ghiaccia? e questi com’ è fitto 104 sì sottosopra? e come, in sì poc’ ora, 105 da sera a mane ha fatto il sol tragitto?».
query.result:
**English:**
100 "Before I pull myself out of the abyss, 101 my master," I said when I was upright, 102 "speak to me a little to free me from error:
103 where is the ice? and how is this one fixed 104 upside down? and how, in such a short time, 105 has the sun made its journey from evening to morning?"
**Old English:**
100 "Ær ðam ðe ic of ðam abysse me aþreote, 101 min lareow," cwæð ic ða ða ic rihte wæs, 102 "to ði ðe ðu me of dysige alyse lythwon:
103 hwær is se is? and hu is ðes swa fæste 104 swa uppon niðere? and hu, on swa lytlum fæce, 105 of æfen to mergen hæfð se sunne gefaren?"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
106 Ed elli a me: «Tu imagini ancora 107 d’esser di là dal centro, ov’ io mi presi 108 al pel del vermo reo che ’l mondo fóra.
query.result:
**English:**
106 And he said to me: "You still imagine 107 that you are on the other side of the center, where I seized 108 the hair of the evil worm that pierces the world.
**Old English:**
106 And he sæde to me: "Þu wēnst gēna 107 ðæt þu sỹ on ðære healfe ðæs middes, þær ic fēng 108 on ðæs wyrmes fell ðe ðone world towearp.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
109 Di là fosti cotanto quant’ io scesi; 110 quand’ io mi volsi, tu passasti ’l punto 111 al qual si traggon d’ogne parte i pesi.
query.result:
**English:**
109 From there you fell as far as I descended; 110 when I turned, you passed the point 111 to which all weights are drawn from every side.
**Old English:**
109 Of ðonan ðu feolle swa feor swa ic feol; 110 ða ic me bewende, ðu ðone stede oferferde 111 ðe ælc wæge to zeteð of æzhwilcere healfe.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
112 E se’ or sotto l’emisperio giunto 113 ch’è contraposto a quel che la gran secca 114 coverchia, e sotto ’l cui colmo consunto
115 fu l’uom che nacque e visse sanza pecca; 116 tu haï i piedi in su picciola spera 117 che l’altra faccia fa de la Giudecca.
query.result:
**English:**
112 And if you are now arrived beneath the hemisphere 113 that is opposite to that which the great expanse of dry land 114 covers, and beneath whose summit he who was born and lived without sin 115 was consumed, 116 you have your feet on a small sphere 117 that forms the other face of Judea.
**Old English:**
112 And gif ðu nu eart under ðam heofonclyfe 113 ðe is ðam widmeten ðe ða miclan drýgan 114 oferwreoh, and under ðam heofonhweorfe 115 wæs se man geboren and butan synnum leofode; 116 ðu hæfst ðine fet on ðære lytlan sfæran 117 ðe ðære Iudeiscan eorðan oðre healfe wyrcð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
118 Qui è da man, quando di là è sera; 119 e questi, che ne fé scala col pelo, 120 fitto è ancora sì come prim’ era.
query.result:
**English:**
118 Here it is morning, while there it is evening; 119 and he who made a ladder for us with his hair, 120 is still fixed in the same way as he was before.
**Old English:**
118 Hér is morgen, ðær hit is æfen; 119 and se ðe ús hider stige gegearwode, 120 he is giet ðær he ær wæs.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
121 Da questa parte cadde giù dal cielo; 122 e la terra, che pria di qua si sporse, 123 per paura di lui fé del mar velo,
124 e venne a l’emisperio nostro; e forse 125 per fuggir lui lasciò qui loco vòto 126 quella ch’appar di qua, e sù ricorse».
query.result:
**English:**
121 From this side he fell down from heaven; 122 and the earth, which had previously jutted out here, 123 through fear of him made a veil of the sea,
124 and came to our hemisphere; and perhaps 125 to flee from him she left here a void space 126 that which appears on this side, and ran back up.
**Old English:**
121 Of ðissum ende he feoll of heofonum; 122 and ðeos eorðe, ðe ær ðisum wearð, 123 for ðære fyrhte his geworhte ðæs sæes wrigels,
124 and com to ðissum middangearde; and efne 125 for ðære fluhte his he forlet her stowe weste 126 ða ðe her on ðissum ende æteowð, and up gewende.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
127 Luogo è là giù da Belzebù remoto 128 tanto quanto la tomba si distende, 129 che non per vista, ma per suono è noto
130 d’un ruscelletto che quivi discende 131 per la buca d’un sasso, ch’elli ha roso, 132 col corso ch’elli avvolge, e poco pende.
query.result:
**English:**
127 There is a place down there, far from Beelzebub, 128 as far as the tomb extends, 129 which is known not by sight, but by sound,
130 of a streamlet that descends there 131 through the hole of a rock, which it has gnawed, 132 with a course that it winds and hardly slopes.
**Old English:**
127 Þær is stede beȝeondan Belzebubbe feor 128 swa feor swa hellegrund astihþ, 129 þe nis na for gesihþe ac for sweȝe cuþ
130 of wætre þe þær of dune síȝeþ 131 þurh stanes þuru þe he þurhgnáȝ, 132 mid þam ræse þe he onwríþ and lyt swigþ.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
133 Lo duca e io per quel cammino ascoso 134 intrammo a ritornar nel chiaro mondo; 135 e sanza cura aver d’alcun riposo,
136 salimmo sù, el primo e io secondo, 137 tanto ch’i’ vidi de le cose belle 138 che porta ’l ciel, per un pertugio tondo.
query.result:
**English:**
133 The leader and I, by that hidden path, 134 entered to return to the bright world; 135 and without caring to take any rest,
136 we climbed up, he first and I second, 137 so much that I saw of the beautiful things 138 that heaven bears, through a round opening.
**Old English:**
133 Se heretoga and ic ðurh ðone weg behyd 134 eodon ongean ðone sciran middangeard; 135 and butan ymbhogan æniges restes,
136 stigon upp, he forma and ic æfter, 137 oððæt ic geseah ðara fægerra ðinga 138 ðe heofon bær, ðurh ðone engan stede.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
139 E quindi uscimmo a riveder le stelle.
query.result:
**English:**
139 And so we emerged to see the stars again.
**Old English:**
139 And ða we út eodon to geseonne ða steorran eft.
